instruction: What kinds of spectrum were used in the experiment to classify cervical pathological tissues?
Output: In the experiment, Raman spectral data and fast Fourier transform (FFT) amplitude information were used to classify cervical pathological tissues.

instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were used to classify cervical pathological tissues?
Output: Partial least squares (PLS) and extreme gradient boosting (XGBoost) were used for feature selection to obtain the first 30-dimensional features. Fast Fourier transform (FFT) was also used to obtain amplitude information, and then PLS and XGBoost were used to obtain the first 30-dimensional features.

instruction: What metric was chosen to evaluate the classification accuracies of different models to classify cervical pathological tissues?
Output: The specific metric used to classify cervical pathological tissues was classifiaction accuracy and AUC-ROC.

instruction: What machine learning algorithms were used to establish the classification models for different cervical pathological tissues in the experiment?
Output: The machine learning algorithms used to establish the classification models for different cervical pathological tissues in the experiment were K nearest neighbor (KNN), extreme learning machine (ELM), artificial bee colony support vector machine (ABC-SVM), support vector machine optimized by the cuckoo search algorithm (CS-SVM), particle swarm optimization coupled with support vector machine (PSO-SVM), and the convolutional neural network combined with long- and short-term memory (CNN-LSTM).

instruction: How does feature fusion improve the model performance in classifying different cervical pathological tissues using Raman spectral data and various machine learning algorithms?
Output:
Feature fusion improves the model performance in classifying different cervical pathological tissues using Raman spectral data and various machine learning algorithms by combining multiple sets of features obtained from different preprocessing techniques. In the related experiment, two preprocessing techniques were used: partial least squares (PLS) and fast Fourier transform (FFT). 

First, PLS was used to reduce the dimensionality of the Raman spectral data, resulting in the first 30-dimensional features. Then, extreme gradient boosting (XGBoost) was applied for feature selection, further refining the feature set. 

Additionally, the Raman spectral data was processed using FFT to obtain amplitude information. PLS and XGBoost were again used to obtain the first 30-dimensional features from this amplitude information. 

The classification models used in the experiment included K nearest neighbor (KNN), extreme learning machine (ELM), artificial bee colony support vector machine (ABC-SVM), support vector machine optimized by the cuckoo search algorithm (CS-SVM), particle swarm optimization coupled with support vector machine (PSO-SVM), and the convolutional neural network combined with long- and short-term memory (CNN-LSTM).
